However, it was a simple story and probably slightly less adult than 'Bruce' meaning that it is more accessible for family viewing. I could watch it with my Nan or with my Nephew, if my Nan hadn't passed away and my nephew was ever at home, but you get the point.

I don't need to rush to watch it again and I will probably only come back to it in years to come, as I see it whilst flicking through the TV, but I wouldn't be adverse to watching it every week if I suddenly had a child that was obsessed with it (The chance would be a fine thing). Oh Mr. Carell! How far you've fallen! After a glowing moment in LITTLE MISS SUNSHINE, Steve Carell's choice of films is beginning to contrast starkly with what has come since. Although THE 40 YEAR OLD VIRGIN was entertaining, it was dwarfed by his "Sunshine" character. Hoping to find something that'd get me to spew popcorn from my nose, I decided to rent EVAN ALMIGHTY and see what possible guffaws might await me here. Not much...

Given the trite and clichéd script, the entire film felt forced and unemotional. Poking a bit of fun at flagging family values and the current U.S. administration's take on the environment, Evan Almighty also tries to put a profound biblical moment into humorous terms but fails miserably.

Nearly every person on Earth knows the story of Noah and The Ark. God's wrath was sent down with 30 days and nights of rain which flooded the entire planet while Noah, his family, and two of each of His creatures on Earth rode out the wetness in relative comfort via the gopher wood ark. It was a huge moment in human history (if you believe the biblical text).

So why would God appear to one man and ask him to build an ark that would only carry the world's animals for a few minutes after a dam break? The simple answer is that He never would. Too much emphasis was given to U.S. government policy and not enough on world events, making Evan Almighty a terribly myopic and Ameri-centric film. Although designed as a comedy, it really never reaches anything approaching belly laughs. Maybe a few grunts and a smile, but little else.

John Goodman (CARS) pulls in another forced performance as the despicable Congressman Chuck Long who's only goals are to create development opportunities on protected national land holdings. Even the strong presence of Morgan Freeman (10 ITEMS OF LESS) as God can't help mop up this soaking wet disaster-of-a-film.

The only funny moments are between Carell and the animals, especially as Evan learns what animal magnetism is REALLY like. Birds literally flock to him. Sheep herd around him. Lions take pride in being near him (please forgive the puns).

The special effects were fun to watch but were brief (with good reason). The "flood" was interesting in that the Ark was obviously guided by His hand and shoved in just the right direction.

But other than that you're in for little more than an insult to common sense and intellect.

"Evan Almighty," directed by Tom Shadyac, is a family-friendly comedy that serves as a loose sequel to "Bruce Almighty." Steve Carell stars as Evan Baxter, a newly elected congressman who is divinely tasked with building an ark in preparation for a great flood. Carell brings his signature comedic timing and likability to the role, making Evan's transformation from a self-absorbed politician to a modern-day Noah both humorous and endearing.

The film's humor is light and accessible, making it suitable for viewers of all ages. Morgan Freeman reprises his role as God, delivering a calm and wise performance that complements Carell's more frantic energy. The special effects, especially involving the animals, are impressive and add to the film's whimsical charm.

However, the plot is quite predictable and lacks the originality that made its predecessor so appealing. The message about environmental stewardship and faith is heartfelt but delivered in a somewhat heavy-handed manner. Despite its shortcomings, "Evan Almighty" offers enough laughs and heartwarming moments to make it an enjoyable, if not particularly memorable, family comedy.

review_title: Very Funny and Not Just For Kids

review_title: Despite being one of the better "Carrey-less" sequels to a Jim Carrey comedy, this colossal waste of money in no way justifies its existence
review_detailed_main:
Evan Baxter (Steve Carell) has left his job as Buffalo, New York's lead anchorman for Channel 7 news and has now won a bid as a Congressman from the city. Evan along with his wife Joan (Lauren Graham), and three sons Dylan (Johnny Simmons) the eldest, Jordan (Graham Phillips) the middle son, and Ryan (Jimmy Bennett) the youngest move to Prestige Crest in Virginia for Evan's new job. Evan finds himself approached by senior congressman Chuck Long (John Goodman) for the opportunity to co-sponsor Long's Citizens' Integration of Public Lands Act which leads to a sizable time commitment from Evan leading to delaying spending time with his family. After praying to God to give him the power to change the world, mysterious packages containing old tools and bundles of lumber are sent to Evan from Alpha and Omega Hardware. The sender is eventually revealed to be God (Morgan Freeman) who assigns Evan the task of building an Ark. As the pressures of building the Ark mount Evan finds himself pulled in multiple directions.

Following the success of Bruce Almighty becoming the fifth highest grossing film of 2003, Universal was keen on continuation. A screenplay titled The Passion of the Ark written by Bobby Florsheim and Josh Stolberg became the subject of a multi studio bidding war with Sony Pictures eventually acquiring the spec script for $2.5 million, then a record for a screenplay from unproduced writers. Universal made a deal with Sony to co-produce the script as a sequel to Bruce Almighty with Steve Oedekerk who re-wrote the first film assigned to re-write the sequel only for the studio to discard the script entirely and have Oedekerk start from scratch. Carrey was asked to reprise his role as Bruce for the film but declined due to being uninterested in reprising characters and when it became clear Carrey wasn't going to agree director Tom Shadyac convinced Steve Carell to reprise his role as Evan Baxter with the film being repurposed as a spin-off. The film was authorized with a budget of $140 million becoming the most expensive comedy ever made, and coupled with set construction costs, the scale and enormity of the visual effects, and the issues involved with filming and caring for the various animals the final budget for Evan Almighty was estimated at somewhere between $175-200 million to the point Sony got cold feet on the project and handed control entirely over to Universal. Universal defended the costs as the film was designed as a "four quadrant tentpole" so the broad commercial appeal justified the budget size. The film was made with a PG rating as opposed to the PG-13 of the original film, and was more specifically targeted towards families and church going crowds with its marketing. Upon release the film received negative reviews from critics and despite opening at the top of the box office, Evan's $31 million opening weekend was considering less from Bruce's $67 million and the film fizzled out with a final world wide total of $174 million making the film a substantial loss for Universal. While none of the cast were affected as all of their careers continued with no repercussions, Tom Shadyac's deal with Universal was terminated shortly thereafter and to date Shadyac has not directed a major tentpole or studio comedy since. Evan Almighty isn't offensively awful like some Carrey-less sequels, but it's also not very good either.

Despite Steve Carell reprising his role as Evan Baxter, the character has had his edges considerable filed down in order to make him a relatable "family comedy everyman" including retconning the character into having a loving family with three sons. This is a major problem with the movie because much of the humor in this film is derived from Evan being subjected to various humiliations and indignities foisted upon him by God such as being followed and pestered by animals, having his beard grow uncontrollably similar to the gag from The Santa Clause, or forcing Evan to wear only biblical robes. While I wasn't the biggest fan of Bruce Almighty, at least the underlying core of that film made sense in trying to teach Bruce some kind of lesson about humanity and having a personal locus of control. In Evan Almighty it's like they took the feeling Bruce had of "God being a kid with a magnifying glass and an anthill" and building their premise out of that. While it's not unthinkable God doing this kind of stuff could be funny, Evan isn't presented as being unlikable enough to warrant being subjected to this kind of treatment especially since Evan is nowhere near as abrasive or jerky as he was in Bruce Almighty and aside from being a neat freak and driving a Hummer there's not much to Evan (aside from a stupid dance that's a running gag).

Evan Almighty doesn't really have much in the way of laughs or humor to show for its $175 million+ budget and what chuckles we get from the cast are purely from delivery and not from writing. But while Evan Almighty doesn't bring the funny, it does bring elaborate sets, large scale animal choreography and visual effects galore...none of which are funny. Whenever visual effects are used in this movie, they're not used in service of anything humorous or silly (with the exception of a multitude of poop jokes) but rather they're in service of creating scenes of either awe or devastation. A big reason for this movie's ballooned budget was the climactic flood sequence involving the Ark going through DC (which begs the question of why there are two of every animal if the world isn't flooding) and while impressive looking it's not funny nor does it feel like it's trying to be.

Evan Almighty is just a waste of money. It's a comedy that isn't funny but at least it's not overly painful like certain other comedies I've seen. There's a reason family audiences ditched this movie in favor of Ratatouille, because that film had beautiful visuals AND humor and this film is a comedy with no major laughs and just pretty visuals.

However, every time I start to enjoy Evan Almighty, it does something overly cheesy or ridiculous and undercuts any positive emotions I was feeling. review_title: Assumes the audience is stupid and cuts poorly

The narrative is poorly structured and flipflops for more than half the movie. None of Evan's decisions were well motivated or even rationalized a bit - at least respect the audience's intelligence. Although maybe that's just a reflection of the religious crowd it's marketed to.

We get it, have faith in god - that makes for really bad story telling however.

It was littered with basic continuity errors that should have never happened at all.

Definitely a Netflix and chill choice, it's either a great movie to rip on together or one you won't regret not finishing.

I quite enjoyed the original "Bruce Almighty" movie which centred on a then-at-his-peak Jim Carrey, where Steve Carell's Evan Baxter was a supporting character. This revisiting of the idea of Morgan Freeman's white-suited God picking another hapless human to carry out his instructions and so avert a great disaster while of course coincidentally re-connect with his wife and family, is diminished by its return, although early in the movie there is some palatable humour and while the ending is highly contrived, there is still some C-Gen SFX to catch the eye.

Carell, whose career-profile in Hollywood as risen as Carrey's has fallen their earlier "Almighty" appearances, does his best to carry the film, but that feeling of déjà-vu from the plotting from before, is off-putting. However, the film deliberately isn't as racy as Carrey's Bruce outing, not necessarily a bad thing but the urge for going for the family audience, or at least the mawkish sentimentality which accompanies it certainly shoukd have been resisted.

It's really a movie of two halves, Carell's gradual morphing in the first half into a modern- day Noah, head-to-toe air and robe to match, is fairly humorous but the second half founders as it strives for spectacle and adventure, at the expense, unfortunately, of the laugh count.

Still, Carell as I said, is pleasantly engaging, Morgan Freeman earns an easy pay-day as God Part 2 and John Goodman, bad toupee and all (I'm guessing it was deliberate) gets to ham it up as a self-aggrandising politician.

The film is definitely at the featherweight end of the light entertainment scale, but as undemanding family fun goes, it did its job.

review_title: A Mixed Bag of Chuckles and Over-the-Top Spectacle that Struggles to Capture the Magic of its Predecessor

The film features Steve Carell's comedic prowess in the lead role and combines physical comedy with heartfelt messages about faith and family. However, the ambitious CGI sequences and slapstick humor sometimes overshadow the subtle comedic moments, making the film feel more like a spectacle than a seamless continuation of the Bruce Almighty narrative. Despite its shortcomings, Evan Almighty has moments of genuine humor and a positive message about faith and environmental stewardship. The cast, including Lauren Graham and John Goodman, delivers enjoyable performances, but the film's ambitious scope and heavy-handed delivery may leave audiences with mixed feelings.

During the disillusioned late-1970's Carl Reiner made the smart and funny "Oh, God!", a film about God's search for a spokesman in the form a so-called atheist grocery store employee played by John Denver. That film served up two sequels. The Almighty series is beginning to have a similar vibe, in a similar unpredictable time of emotional recession.

The film is cute and oh-so-wholesome, but its third act undercuts the entire film, much of the cast is under-used, and it's simply too preachy for its own good.

Okay, it's nothing special and it's nowhere near as funny or imaginative as its predecessor, but for entertainment value it isn't that bad.

Steve Carrell is good as Evan, but he's certainly no Jim Carrey, who has an effortless ability to get laughs out of any material. The plot is original but also predictable and typical of a family film, with by far the best part of the film being its ending. It makes the very average first three-quarters of the film worthwhile with some brilliant special effects and cinematography. 'Evan Almighty' is an average family adventure film. It's certainly not as good as its predecessor but also not as bad as some would have you believe.

This certainly isn't a comedy - I don't know what it was marketed that way. As a serious movie, it lacks any sort of substance. Unless you're fresh out of Sunday school or needing your Noah fix, you'll find yourself bored to tears.

The supporting cast took away from what little of the movie was left. Lauren Graham plays an empty housewife with no real depth. His children don't really add anything to the movie. They seem to be around solely to brood about their absent father at the beginning. Jonah Hill plays a creepy internet addict that doesn't come off as humorous.

I found the original to be a decent movie. Disappointed that this one didn't really go anywhere.

Surprisingly, Evan Almighty is not a comedy per se. A sequel to the Jim Carrey movie Bruce Almighty, where Steve Carrell played a television journalist Evan Baxter - the one with the rubbery face giving Jim a run for his own money, this movie is sans Jim, and Steve is thrust into the leading role, with writer Steve Oedekerk (the one who gave us androgynous Barnyard cows) providing Evan Baxter a fast track in his career, to that of a newly elected Congressman.

What Evan Almighty is, is serious family drama. For anyone out there working hard (read: workaholic), this story is a reminder on the finer, more important things in life, and that is family ties, and never to neglect your kids as they are growing up. To anyone bringing home the bacon like Evan Baxter (and to feed that fuel guzzler of a vehicle), these work-life balance scenarios are sometimes more myth than can be actually achieved. Building his campaign on the promise of Changing the World, he now has to deliver those election vows, much to the dismay of his wife and kids whom he had uprooted and moved to new suburbia.

And like The Willow Tree - not that this movie is as classic as that - be careful what you wish for from the Old Man upstairs, as sometimes he has a strange sense of humour, or wanting to teach you how to fish rather than grant you that fish himself. Ask and you shall receive, but you know not in what form that wish will come in. There's a poignant moment, for those who make requests from time to time, that the Almighty provides an opportunity for you to achieve something, rather than providing you with that something without you earning for it, or presenting it on a silver platter. Miracles don't come easy nor cheap these days.

Morgan Freeman reprises his role as God. One of my favourite character actors, I felt he has immense presence in whatever roles he takes on, and it's no wonder he's given this manifestation of the supreme being. There was a slight tongue-in-cheek moment in the story where he referred himself as a storyteller of sorts, and those who have followed Freeman's career roles (I've only done so for the last 25 years or so), would know that's a reference to his days as the Easy Reader on the Electric Company.

Thanks to 40 Year Old Virgin, we do know Steve Carrell is kind of hairy, and as Evan Baxter turns into Noah, this wealth of hair comes into great use. But Steve's not Jim, and the story doesn't allow Steve to exhibit any kind of physical comedy, unless you count the repeated falling from heights funny, or his trying his darndest best to escape from animals who come calling, making him seem like a reel alternative to Eddie Murphy's Dr Doolittle. It takes while for Evan to finally resign himself to God's commandment, and that actually doomed the movie to some uninspiring scenes just going through the motions, which the trailers have more than covered with the skeptics doubting and mocking Evan as Noah. Even Steve's little crazy jig expires after a while.

The supporting cast of John Goodman, Lauren Graham from the Gilmore Girls, and Wanda Sykes all seem to be playing caricatures, and amongst the three, Sykes unfortunately turned out to be the most irritating of the lot, spouting one-liners so bad, you'll cringe in your seat. But one-dimensional characters aside, Evan Almighty did boast some nicely done, especially when you see the ark in its final glory and gets put into some use, reminiscent however of a turkey of a movie in Speed 2: Cruise Control.

Evan Almighty could probably join the list of sequels that shouldn't be made, but tear away its association with its predecessor, it might work as a standalone given the strong human emotions, and its cursory statements on environmental issues should it be paid more attention to. Saving the earth, saving the animals are contemporary themes these days, and with the reminder on performing Acts of Random Kindness, there are moments when watching the movie that you'll nod your head in concurrence.

I love Steve Carrell, and I love Morgan Freeman, so I can't understand why either of them would be involved in a movie like this that goes out of its way to avoid being entertaining.

Apparently it's supposed to be a comedy but there is not one single amusing moment in the entire movie. Even horror films usually have at least one joke, so it's amazing that this movie manages to be so steadfastly mirthless.

The plot is somehow incredibly tedious AND annoying. It comes across as a really weird advert for an old testament religious cult.

I can't understand how it got written or made, who it is for, or why anyone would ever watch it.

Truly this film is offensively unwatchable.

This was a great movie, being able to bring noahs ark into the mix is great. I always liked evan in Bruce Almighty I thought it was good they made a movie for him as well, it would've been good for Bruce (Jim Carrey) to pop up but he didn't. A great story with great cast some returning some new, altogether this was a great movie, I do enjoy Steve Carrell in movies I think he's hilarious, and always a pleasure to see Morgan Freeman again.

Incredible movie to watch you would definafely enjoy it, highly recommend!

Perfect for family movie night, this has everything you'd want - a wholesome story with a good moral, funny animals, no slow bits and humour for the whole family.

My kids were laughing out loud through the whole thing and I laughed with them. Sure it's silly, but without being crass or rude. Just good clean fun. Apart from the bird poo!

review_title: Depth-lacking liberal media/public burns this one
review_detailed_main: Currently 5.4/10 on IMDb and just 37 Metascore. Are those truly representative of the quality of this production ? Nope. This is the story of a congressman whose career is going strong and whose social status keeps rising, but lacks that which is most important in his life: family chemistry and strength. He tries hard but fails badly at satisfying on both fronts. One day, he meets 'God', who has a mission for him. The film does a great job at being inspired by a previous film, 'Bruce Almighty', while never being anything of a mere sequel, and while standing alone on its own. There is great depth in this film in that Evan is chosen to do a job of biblical proportions, in a pragmatic world that believes in nothing but power and money, and that through this trying adversity, is the coming together of a family, that finally finds love. The dialog is very subtle in places: I remember especially when God talks to Evan's wife in the restaurant, very deep. It's not surprising the cinema people wouldn't like this film that much, although it is certainly troubling. Very solid film, very well written, original, well acted out, strong from start to finish makes for a smooth viewing with humor, depth and, for once, a true message.

Such fun I seem to watch often while tired every few weeks on HBO even then I love all the wholesome vibes and connections to the Bible regardless of religious views it's a great film. Not really a comedy like Bruce Almighty was but Evan Almighty is very light on the soul, shame it's not more appreciated! Plenty of charm, awesome cast, phenomenal coincidences, and just nice entertainment for 96 minutes. Easy to bash but not as cheesy as Tooth Fairy that I watched previously. For a movie that has tremendous connections to the Bible and a little bit of 40 Year Old Virgin it's a so good to me I've always enjoyed even 15 years ago!

review_title: Playful, modern and comedic biblical remake...
review_detailed_main:
I read through a stream of hateful reviews by people who frankly were threatened by the unabashed use of biblical tropes, most of whom didn't even try to veil the intent or motive of their discomfort.

This movie is a funny, family film for people of all creeds with a feel-good approach and packs in star-power. If you are religious, it's an intelligent homage to a story you have heard many times. In some cases can be thought provoking and exemplary of the modern challenges of being a god fearing individual within a vessel of Judeo-Christian lore, but should be approachable for any religion and does so without being preachy. It may very well have more to offer for those that are not previously exposed to these tropes, and our not threatened by the notion of a God.

For those that aren't or consider themselves a non-believer, all the same, in a world of larger than life super heroes dominating our ideas of what is supernatural and coupled with their ability to captivate all viewers- the various depictions and biblical interactions can be explained away by an intelligent parent that understands the use of parable in literature and film as a way to teach a lesson as opposed to some veiled attempt to convert you which it rigidly is not. In this sense, while much lighter fare than a Marvel epic I see no reason why the same suspense of disbelief for Evan Almighty would suddenly be unwarranted.

Such an awesome movie hated by the godless critics of Hollywood. No surprise there. Loved every minute of this wonderful movie. It is funny, fun, uplifting, hilarious and sends a positive message to society. If you didn't love this movie, I feel sorry for your soul.

review_title: God Wants Americans To Protect The Wilderness From Destruction!

review_detailed_main: I LOVED this movie. And so did my husband, who wasn't sure he was going to like it. There were symbols and signs that were extremely accurate to the story of Noah, and I really like that, because it shows that someone actually took the time to research before making the movie. The acting was very good, the costumes, it just felt and seemed genuine. It really shows how a man who cared only about making a name for himself changed into someone who cared about everyone and everything around him, which is the way we all should be. I will see this again, and again, and I will definitely recommend it. It's not just a comedy, I don't know what to call it. But I really liked it.

This is a great family film! Everyone should go and take ALL the children. This movie is extremely funny. But also, it's a great lesson about walking in faith!!! Evan Almighty is a movie ALL Christians should see. Hollywood got the message about making an extremely good family film and making films with no cussing, good values, real comedy that is based on a historical Bible story! We were most impressed with the writers who lined up Genesis 6:14 in the story line, as well as A.R.K. One "act of random kindness" at a time. Very enjoyable.

We hope more movies will be made with decent humor and intellectual, well-written dialog.

For once, Hollywood has put out a decent movie. I would encourage everyone to buy this DVD. It' light-hearted, funny, clean, and has a good positive message. It's great fun for the whole family. It does have one cuss word in it. But, the context actually makes it funny. Also, here is no sex in this movie whatsoever; and may I say that I am RELIEVED! Something can be funny without putting in all the sexual content. It's got a great message about sticking by the ones you love, keeping family together, having enough faith to do the impossible, and conserving our planet. Overall, it was a great feature. I would LOVE to see Hollywood put more movies out like this. It was good, clean, fun. YES!!!!

Reading the bad reviews of this movie, it seems most people who hate it object to the "Christian overtones." That anger is misplaced, since the Biblical account of the Flood occurs thousands of years before Christ. What they object to is a belief in God, who is portrayed in this movie as an all-powerful but loving and caring being. If you hate that image of God, you won't like this film either.

Personally, I found much to enjoy in this film, from the acting to the scenery. Recommend!

I went in ready to be disappointed. I was ready to be offended.

I came out beaming.

Evan Almighty is a brilliant picture, but one I fear may be under-appreciated because of the beauty and childlike innocence present in it.

The performances were spectacular -- Steve Carell is brilliant as always. It was absolutely hilarious and contained a beautiful message besides. You can't ask for more.

It has made me happy, peaceful, and given me a new view on the Flood Story. It has inspired me. And if I die and find that God is like Morgan Freeman, I wouldn't be the least bit disappointed.

review_title: Evan Almighty: Morgan Freeman second time quite timely!
review_detailed_main: A good PG rated family film comedy beats everything out there hands down! Director Tom Shadyac has come up with a film that offends no one and anyone can come away with a great belly laugh and a good feeling all at the same time. The American Family has been shown to be at it's weakest when the children begin to question the logic of one or both of the parents. In Evan Almighty it is the father who begins to throw caution to the wind to gain back the trust and faith of his three sons. His wife questions his strange back to nature methods until she too joins the family tree. Here in the family is 'reborn' and the laughter never stops! The humor in Evan Almighty is most similar to the film, The Incredibles. While your children are laughing at one joke, you as an adult will be laughing at the punch line which follows the previous jocularity. Your children will believe you are laughing at the same joke that they are but the pun is on them. Parnethood puns partiality preclude precise palindrome. In other words let us all enjoy a good bit of tomfoolery at the movies and let no one be the target of the joke!

review_title: Go See This Movie - Ignore the Critics
review_detailed_main: With such low ratings by the critics I expected little from this movie but discovered much. I rarely hear an audience of adults laughing out loud repeatedly during a movie -- Evan Almighty did this! How? With impressive computer graphic generated animal sight gags, with near perfect timing, especially by Wanda Sykes who played Rita, and by Morgan Freeman who has now officially replaced George Burns as God. You will laugh, you will cry, you will not be sorry you went to this movie unless . . . you have a bias against religion (as many critics do); you will resent this movie deeply as it dares to suggest there is a spiritual side of life -- so don't go and say negative things as it wasn't meant for you.

review_title: After a long drought, a great movie!
review_detailed_main: This was just what I was looking for with my family. Something entertaining, funny, and not offensive. I think many reviewers have watched far too many crapola movies and so they don't recognize a good one. Great message...everyone should see it. The special effects were awesome. Carrell was funny, funny. He was a great choice. Sikes was great with her one liners. All the variety of animals and how well trained they were was fascinating. Any lag in comedy was quickly over and more than made up for with the other great features of this film. Much better than the other choices Hollywood has thrown at us lately. It has been months since I have gone to a film,just because there are none of interest. There is so much good in this movie, everyone should see it.

review_title: Good, Clean, Family Fun! (even with a Christian's point of view!)
review_detailed_main: Evan Baxter (Steve Carell) just won an election to be Congressman, and he moves away to 'Prestige Hills' with his wife Joan (Lauren Graham)and his three sons. Shortly after, a tool box mysteriously appears on his porch. And the next day lumbar appears! Animals from all over start to follow him around. God (Morgan Freeman) tells Evan that there is going to be a flood, and he wants him to build an ark. His hair on his head and face start to grow so rapidly, that as soon as he shaves it off, it grows right back! What is he to do? God soon tells him that there is a dead line as well. September 22 mid-day. Will Evan be able to make the ark before the deadline, trust God, and convince his family to help him? As a Christian, we were not sure what it would be like. Take your family, church, everyone to see this wonderful movie! This movie is good, clean, family fun. (It's very funny too!)
Loved this movie from start to finish. The message of obedience and faithfulness hits so hard. So glad they made it. Well done!!

review_title: One of the best movies of our time
review_detailed_main: Wow. I did not expect this movie to be so profound. Legendary actor Steve Carell kills it in this endlessly humorous and thrilling film. Sure it may have lost a few million dollars, but it was completely worth it to capture this masterpiece on film.

I was surprised at the lack of cursing and the way belief in God was portrayed with an everyday honesty. VERY well done. I enjoyed Bruce Almighty, but found the sexuality a bit much for my grade school age daughter. She is ten now, and there wasn't a single time I cringed or worried about what she saw or heard. I can't remember the last time I could say that about a PG film.

The jokes were funny for many age levels, and the resolution was a bit of surprise. We will see it again, and will likely purchase this film when it appears on DVD.

I highly recommend it for Steve Carell fans, and for Christians who want family fare.

review_title: Why Did This Rate So Low!?
A decent movie, very well made! Stop winning people.
review_detailed_main:
OK, Bruce Almighty was one of a kind, good and funny. Evan Almighty is not Bruce Almighty, we gathered that. Question, why would we expect it to be? For once I am glad this movie took a slightly different direction to be something more than a mere sequel, and I believe they have totally done it. It doesn't even feel like there was a Bruce Almighty before it, if it wasn't for Morgan Freeman who is always great to see. And yes, Steve Carrell is not Jim Carrey, yet who cares? Jim Carrey is good but he is overrated. I don't like Steve Carell really , and wasn't expecting much from him or this movie to be honest after having seen this summer's sequels and "blockbusters", but boy am I glad to be able to come in here and leave a positive comment.

This movie totally did it for me. Maybe it wasn't as funny as B.A. but it was funny enough. It was well built, the script and the plot felt complete enough, the acting was very good, the effects great. Most importantly, I followed the entire movie without being annoyed or getting bored, and I even laughed a lot. And the ending, oh I just loved the ending. The kind of climax that Superman Returns so desperately needed but lacked poorly. Now, there were some little things that raised questions or seemed forced, like "How come there were so many kinds of animals just in that specific forest; while it was obvious that only that area was in need of saving, and not all the animals or beings of the world". But, that's the kind of things you can let slip by, 'cause it's just not that relevant.

I had read bad reviews about it beforehand, and wasn't expecting much, but they were really wrong. I am not afraid of going too far when I say that even though I liked all the other great movies of this summer like Pirate of the Caribbean 3, or Spiderman 3, or Fantastic 4 etc, they lacked what this movie gave me, a feeling of completion and satisfaction. I was able to honestly say in the end: "I liked it" which I haven't said once this summer. I don't know why so many people are giving bad reviews about this film; it's a good one and they're just being too harsh and expecting I don't know what.

Go see this movie and try to enjoy it without prejudice. Trust me, you will.

In the end; I would give this movie a 7.5 or 8 score but only because I think most of the bad reviews in here are unfair, I'm giving it a 9.

Tung!

This is an excellent children's movie to watch. I went and watched Evan Almighty twice over the weekend. I must say this is one of those movies that is funnier the second time you watch it. It is more for children than adults. There are jokes that only adults will understand, but there is maybe only one that could be offensive. It is also a great way to educate your child about the bible. I think it is a great way to bond with a family member of any kind. The animals in the movie are very well trained and the visual effects are outstanding. If you liked Bruce Almighty, then you will enjoy this movie. If your looking for a movie that will make you laugh and leave the theater happy, then this is a sure bet.

review_title: A Sweet, Funny Film Well Worth the Ticket Price
review_detailed_main: So Evan Almighty is getting crappy reviews, but I have to disagree with most of the complaints. It's not an edgy, fast-paced, pure comedy but it's a genuinely likable, sweet, and funny parable that I absolutely loved. The negative reviews could have to to with the expectations for a film with such a big budget; the critics may have been expecting something more Star Wars-ish with guffaws. Oh, well. I hope the movie is successful in spite of the reviews, that people check it out for themselves and not rely of the critics to make that decision for them. Tom Shadyac and Steve Carell have taken a chance with a movie that has a universal spiritual message (IMHO) and doesn't have to cut anyone down to present it. Plus, it's just plain fun!

If you are looking for Jim Carey type humor, then this is not the movie for you. It is not really a sequel to Bruce Almighty. But if you are looking for a warm, funny family film, then Evan Almighty is a winner. Despite the theme, it is not really religious but rather a movie about family sticking together and having faith. Steve Carrell is outstanding and Morgan Freeman is wonderful, as always. Wanda Sykes is very funny as well. It is rare to find a movie that both kids and adults can enjoy without one party being bored or offended. Don't let the negative reviews sway you - this movie is GREAT for all ages and has a nice message. (Not to mention a pretty funny dance sequence during the credits!)
It's about doing the right thing even when it's not popular. I know it's been done before, but it's still entertaining. "How do you change the world? One Act of Random Kindness at a time" A R K

Simply put: this movie is a comedy, at some points slap stick, with a great overall message. It's not supposed to be that serious although I could see how some might be moved by the message the movie sends. Some parts are cheesy, yes, but that's the point! There's even some action with decent CGI for a movie of this kind.

The acting is great overall and ALL cast members played their parts perfectly in my opinion.

Watch this movie while in a good happy mood and you'll love it. Or even watch it when you're down and it's bound to lighten your mental load.

review_title: This was so much better then I thought!~!

How fun, how humorous, entertaining, and religiously funny is Evan Almighty? Once again, professional critics have missed the boat on a comedy. I go to the movies to have a good timecritics go to harshly critique. And truth be told, it is easier (for me, at least) to write negativity than positively. However, why rip apart a movie which is so genuinely fun to watch? Back in 2003, director Tom Shadyac (Liar Liar, Ace Ventura, Bruce Almighty- lots of Jim Carrey films) brought us Bruce Almighty, a subtle yet fun comedy that featured a god-hating man, Bruce Nolan (Carrey), and the help he eventually receives from God, played by Morgan Freeman. Carrey takes out his anger on fellow newscaster Evan Baxter (Carrell), who snubbed him out of the anchor position. All this leaves Baxter as a walking joke of a man, which is where Bruce Almighty leaves off at.

Some time more than four years must've past in between the movies for the character of Evan Baxter. From being an utter mockery after his joke-newscast in Bruce Almighty, Baxter begins Evan Almighty as a successful politician who is running for senator for the state of New York. His newly introduced (and very Hollywood-like) family support him fully with big fake smiles and very unnatural conversations and horrible dialogue. Something strange happens in the midst of all the good news for Congressman Baxter: messages of Genesis 6:14 start appearing wherever he goes or looks; a delivery man brings packages of wood to Baxter's home labeled as 614 Genesis; his alarm clock wakes him up at 6:14 AM; his new license plate reads GEN 614, and so on. (Incase you were unsure on what Genesis 6:14 is, it's a Bible verse about Noah's Ark.) It's good for a knee-slap or two. Or not. It will, however, bring a smile to your face. All of these odd events are topped off when Morgan Freeman appears in front of Baxter's house and explains just who he is: "I am God." "God" tells Baxter that he must build an ark and save the city from the flood. The more Baxter puts off the task, the more signs of the flood start occurring. Animals of all sorts follow him everywhere. In a cute little scene, nearly every species of bird fly into Baxter's office. When his associates open the door to his office, they see the birds and Baxter's reaction. Funny stuff. In addition to the animals, Baxter also grows irreplaceable facial hair. Try as he may via shaving, none of the hair goes away. Just as a warning, prepare for some funny metro sexual jokes. Perhaps the funniest scene is when Baxter is delivered what appears to be torn robes. Donning them, Baxter resembles a cross between Noah and Jesus. He is a laugh-riot, even if you're not exactly laughing out loud.

Evan Almighty is, at $175 million, the most expensive comedy ever. As one could guess, most of that money goes towards the high count of animals in the movie and the ending scene. With a budget like that, you would expect a crazy amount of special effects. We only get a few, if you don't count the real life animals. Thankfully, the movie didn't seem to be lacking without the excess effects. With an opening weekend of $32.1 million, it seems that the movie isn't on track to earn any money in return, which is a shame. Come on, people! Evan Almighty is fun in its on way, and is a movie that I would definitely recommend.

I watched Evan Almighty with my husband and 3 of our kids last night. I thought it was laugh-out-loud funny and also meaningful as a Christian believer.

My husband and I thought the animals on screen were amazing (kudos to the computer graphics folks) and although we thought the ark moving through the water scenes were a bit cheesy, we all really enjoyed the film.

Obviously not for everyone, but my 29-year-old wife & I (34) really enjoyed this movie. We don't have kids, but thought it was very honest and Steve Carell is fantastic. Morgan Freeman does a great job as well in his role.

If you're not looking for complexity, but just want an uplifting, good-natured film this is a great choice. It also hits on the struggle a lot of us face of whether to listen to or ignore what you should REALLY be doing vs. what YOU think you should be doing.

A movie with heart:

Too many comedies these days go for shock or crudeness to impact the viewer. This movie is great in that it makes you laugh and feel good, not violated.

A fun and refreshing movie. Recommended.

review_title: Best Movie in a LONG Time!
review_detailed_main: Evan Almighty is the best movie I've seen in a LONG time! I laughed so hard -- more than for any other movie -- and the story, acting, just everything was right on the money! I got more than I expected seeing this movie! I didn't see the first movie with Jim Carey but thought it totally hilarious! And it wasn't just me--entire audience was LOL! The hilarious script, story, tying into current times and believable themes made it stand out, not to mention the exceptional acting. After looking on-line about this movie, I completely disagree with the "critics," whoever they are. Seems like they usually are on opposite ends of my enjoyment spectrum! Glad I don't read or value comments first before seeing a movie these days!

Although, I can see why others didn't. To begin with, the movies premise is a little awkward and obviously unrealistic. That's fine. I went into Evan Almighty knowing, for the most part, what the story was about. I wasn't going to say "wow that is unrealistic"...because that is what the movie is, unrealistic.

So if you can get past that step of knowing that the background is totally impossible, nice job. Now you have to ask yourself, "do I enjoy this movie on an entertainment level?" And that is where you may get hung up. I did, but it seems like some didn't.

That is the main problem it seems like. An unrealistic background combined with the fact that it isn't entertaining (to others), hurts the film. Not to mention a few other things.

There are a lot of clichés. Just use your imagination. Obviously, clichés don't make people too angry or otherwise they wouldn't be in so many movies and therefore not be called clichés in the first place. However, Evan Almighty uses them and uses them proudly.

Another problem is the pace. At 90 minutes long the story unfolds pretty quickly, not giving much time for complexity. And that's okay with me. Complexity mixed with PG comedy/family films isn't always a great it.

Bottom line, I enjoyed it. It was a nice movie, not as funny as Bruce Almighty and not even too funny on any level, but entertaining enough for me to go home satisfied. (The funniness was actually provided by the many references to other films).

Not to mention the effects were pretty good.

7/10, worthy enough.

review_title: Evan Almighty isn't as almight as he seems...

review_detailed_main:
I found the movie to be refreshing from all the filthy language or sexual enuendos. It had a great plot and the acting was very well done. I wish there were more movies made in the same venue as this. Funny and telling a good moral story.

I found the acting to be done very well.

From a Christian prospective, this movie portrayed the original story of Noah and the ark very well. It did not distort the concept.

After the credits, the audience we (my wife and I) were with, clapped in cheerful exuberance for such a great movie.

Other people commented to others in the audience how good the movie was.

If your looking for Gore, Swearing, sexual overtones and politically correct obtrusiveness, don't go see this movie.

It does help if you know the Biblical Story of Noah and can see the correlation between the two.

review_title: Comedy With an Extra "Feel Good" Moral
review_detailed_main: My family went to this movie despite the critic rating because we liked Steve Carell. I expected that I would probably regret it and leave the theater thinking I should have listened to the critics. I was wrong. This was a great movie! My husband and I looked at each other and said, "Why do you think it got such a low rating from the critics"? And we both came up with the same answer, "Because it had a message that is almost always unpopular with the critics." We laughed often during this movie and enjoyed the same Steve Carell comedy that we look forward to, but at the same time, we left the theater not only laughing but thinking about life just a little bit more. I suppose the critics prefer to just be entertained. If I can get entertainment, along with a little thought provoking material then I figure I've won the jackpot. I can only imagine a pessimist or cynical person being disappointed in this film -- or maybe someone who does pick apart every aspect of a film. As for the general public, I think we tend to look beyond some of the small stuff in favor of the deeper meaning. Great job by Steve Carell. If you are familiar with Steve Odekerk and enjoyed some of his films, you'll be glad to know that he helped out with this one as well. You can take your kids to this show without fear of what you will need to explain afterward.

review_title: A touch of Carrell, a drop of Freeman, and a lot of water
The Best Family Film of the Summer
review_detailed_main:
If you go to this movie expecting crass, sarcastic humor you will be disappointed. If you go looking for an extremely family friendly film with a lot of positive messages you will be delighted.

It is extremely rare to find a movie that you can take young children to that both they and the adults will enjoy. This is one of those exceptions. Its not uproariously funny but you will leave the theater feeling good and you might just have something to think about.

Approriate for all ages.

Go support this movie - we are planning on going again ASAP and will buy the DVD when it comes out.

The biggest mistake of this movie - marketing. I think people were expecting more of a mainstream comedy than a family friendly movie. I know people who avoided it because they feared it would be mainstream (ie, lots of sexual innuendos and crude humor.) It absolutely has none of that! Enjoy.

My original Title for this review was "OMG! What a Cast + Actors too!" Which may have been a bit too tacky considering the feedback I have received.

WHen I went to see this movie, I was expecting a sacrilegious slapstick comedy. I was satisfied with sufficient sight gags and cheap humor that kept it funny, but did not destroy serious moral lessons or reminders in the Plot. The importance of supportive family, respect for our "God-Given" environment, Faith, Integrity, the price of corruption. But I found myself MORE awe-struck with the grand scale of the Ark and the Animals.

I had a wonderful sense of the Scale of the Original Noah's Ark, and felt connected to the historical significance of this massive construction task with Biblical era tools. I was amused and amazed at the range of animal scenes, especially the humor in their contributions to Ark building. A comedy of immense scale and record cost, but well worth it.

Congrats to all the major players, who did not disappoint me from previous Roles, Especially Morgan Freeman, John Goodman, Lauren Graham, Steve Carell in that order. No disrespect to the Newer or Younger players, where I had no Expectations -- all fine for their roles.

So, enjoy the Humor, Love the Animals, Admire the Actors, Identify with the Struggles and Doubts of the Characters, be Redeemed in the underlying Themes, and above all, for God's Sake, See it on the Big Screen!

I was somewhat hesitant to see the movie, based on the "professional" reviewers at Rottentomatoes.com. My 17-year-old daughter saw it and said she really liked it. Then I read the "professional" reviews, and realized they didn't like it because it didn't glorify premarital sex, or use the F-word 800 times. Actually, I think the real reason they didn't like it was because it actually had a good message, and horrors, mentioned people praying. It wasn't gut-busting funny, but it was funny and a pleasant use of the time in the theater, unlike a lot of movies put out in the past couple of decades. Ironically, one of the funniest parts comes after the official movie end, so don't leave the theater when you see the first credit start.

The writing in this movie is classic specifically some of the one liners.

I especially liked Wanda Sykes lines (What are you shooting- Rogaine?).

The casting also was great. All of the characters complemented each other and Morgan Freeman was great as God. Steve Carroll is rapidly becoming a great comedian.

We need more movies like this one to brighten our days.

Forgot I also wish to thank the animals and congratulate them on their acting.

Keep on Dancing.

review_title: Baffled by the Negative Reviews - It's just not the same type of movie as 'Bruce'!
review_detailed_main:
I'm mildly baffled by the hyper-negative comments on this film. Because of them, and what many critics said as well, I went into this thinking it would be just terrible. I was, however, quite pleasantly surprised. This is a sweet, good-natured film that left me feeling quite happy.

I think what irked the unsatisfied reviewers is that this is absolutely NOT 'Bruce Almighty'. Anyone who expected that is going to be disappointed. I'm sorry that marketing relied so much on billing it as a sequel, because it's really just the same God operating within the same movie world. This is a much more family-oriented and "safe" comedy. Many of the jokes are juvenile at best. The special effects aren't dazzling and the moments where the comedians in the film try to milk their standard style for all it's worth are often just uncomfortably bad. As said in several other reviews as well, Carell is at his worst when he's obviously trying too hard to be Jim Carrey.

But none of those things took away from my enjoyment of the film. The messages were really quite well done and the more subtle bits of humor were fantastic. I thought they did a great job of giving each bizarre biblical occurrence a particular purpose and meaning in the modern story as well. Morgan Freeman's God is, as last time, absolutely wonderful. He's mischievous, good-natured, funny, and great to watch.

I thought 'Bruce Almighty' was pretty forgettable and certainly not some genius comedy that this film doesn't measure up to. It's simply not the same kind of film. I think if you go into it as a family film with some nice messages, you'll enjoy it a lot more.

review_title: touching and heartwarming story about family
review_detailed_main:
It is not a comedy, it is not a fantasy. Where those categories come from?

OK, there is some humour here, but light, few jokes does not make a comedy. It is really great (9/10) movie about love, commitment, trust, and well, it is also about religion. Is your God kept in secret, valid on Sundays only or it is really present in your life. Whole life? However, it is not religious movie, God is mentioned (and well played by M.Freeman) but there is wider context here -- are your beliefs, thinking and acting the same, or you believe in something, think something else, and act quite differently?

What's most important in a gentle way it shows some obvious truths about life -- for example, obstacles are to overcome them, not to despair.

Touching (I admit, in restaurant scene I almost cried), heartwarming movie (beautiful Lauren Graham), with disgusting jokes almost at level zero (rare thing for American movies nowadays), I highly recommend it for watching for whole family. Enjoy!

review_title: Fun Family Film for Once - Rent It
review_detailed_main: We were looking for something fun for our family to watch. We struggle so much with finding something worthwhile anymore. There is so much violence and all my teen wants to do is watch that (too many violent movies are advertised toward teens) - it's hard to find something light-hearted and to make us all laugh. Well, after a lot of debate in the video-store last night we settled on Evan Almighty, which we missed in theaters. And boy, are we glad we picked this movie. We finally had a movie that was just plain funny - yes, so it was a tad goofy at times - but it gave us what we needed - good clean fun and laugh, sometimes, till it brought tears. The animals were great and if you watch the Special Features you can see what was Computer Graphics and what was not. It was a huge undertaking and I thought they did it just right. Open your mind, forgive the mistakes and just laugh. Great case, great animals.
Great for the whole family. Funny and fun. Adults and kids will all enjoy it.

It seems like a long time since I've really enjoyed a movie and laughed out loud in a theatre. This one was great fun. I wasn't the only enjoying it...everyone in the audience was laughing. Wanda Sykes as Rita, Evan's secretary, had and delivered the best lines in the movie. Her timing was spot on. The kids were actually kid like and not little dorks.

The special effects were so well done we wondered which animals were real and which were not. For a change, the crudity was not overstated.

Go and have a good time, laugh and be sure to take your kids. I'm planning to go see it again.

review_title: Glad I Finally Watched the Film
review_detailed_main:
I've not seen Bruce Almighty and I generally avoid movies that portray some writer/director concept of what God is really like. Those kind of movies always miss the mark by so much that they tend to be more offensive than funny. Not this time. Morgan Freeman plays God as benevolent and loving while also firm about his commands being followed.

Steve Carell is not and never should be compared to Jim Carey - just a note to those reviews that attempt to. Both are funny but with such extremely different approaches.

This movie is a fun watch and those who want a side riping comedy, it is not that. But it is refreshing to see a movie that the whole family can go to and enjoy. It is good to see a movie intended to be entertainment yet have a solidly positive message. This is a good movie and I expect I will prefer it to its supposedly prequel - if I ever decide to watch it.

OK I really enjoyed this sequel, although the first one with Jim Carrey is a little better, this one is still pretty funny. I don't know why everyone was giving this such a bad review because I watched it in the middle of the night and I really liked it. I don't think I have ever laughed so much at a PG movie as I did Evan Almighty. Steve Carell is hilarious in this as well as his other films like The 40 Year Old Virgin and his appearances in Bruce Almighty and Anchorman. Morgan Freeman does a good job as god once again and the ending is not only funny, but really cool too. They really put some work into it for this to be a comedy movie. Overall I give this an 8 out of 10 because it was really funny and I liked it. I would recommend this to all Steve Carell fans and all comedy fans who like to watch good clean comedy.

At the time of review the average score is 5.4. If I saw this before seeing the film I wouldn't have bothered. What a feel good movie. I would recommend those of you who just want a light couple of hours entertainment give it a go. Too much emphasis is given to deep, deep films that leave you wondering "What the fu.." (Manchester By The Sea) et al. Watching a film you are supposed to be entertained and I was.

I did not expect this movie to be as good as it was, it was a great laugh. Some religious people may take offence, not only because God is being represented and Noah is being portrayed in the film.

However the film utilises the cast perfectly and God shows his wrath or blessing upon Evan, but just at a time when its exactly what he does not need.

When your a person who takes no risks and wants to go up the ladder and God speaks to you and seems to do tasks of the old ages it seems difficult to do.

Unlike Bruce Almighty, god creates mayhem for Evan and enforces him to grow a beard, wear a robe.... thats difficult and hilarious especially when your in politics. Bruce creates Mahem for himself by increasing his own responsibilities and having dire consequences with his decisions but Evan is given the burden of responsibility as the only way he can continue and there is nothing he can do to avoid it.

The moral of the film, God works in mysterious ways and eventually it will pay out if you follows his given guidance. No matter how difficult the path.

And that's all there is to it.

It's not evil, it's well made, it's very funny and knowing in places.

Only unbelievers will dislike this film.

This is modern Hollywood genius and innocence in one.

Very underrated movie.

Morgan, once again, plays God... Which is not the wonder of this movie. The wonder is in the innocent cleverness of a Hollywood script writer and team actually taking this subject matter seriously to the hilt... and it's not stupid... Yes, it's for the youngsters... But it's a very smart film, and has many subtle touches to believers than one might realise on first viewing.

A very pleasant, amusing, almost divine and lovely use of cinema to try to make people believe in miracles.

And miracles DO happen.

But to really get the most out of them, you not only need a believer, you need believers in the believers.

review_title: Giving this a 10 does not do this film justice!
review_detailed_main:
***** SPOILERS ***** Looking past the 'Crazy Conservative' and 'Silly Believer' overtones, this movie has a much more important message going for it.

God is still in charge, and still loves us. This is not a retake on the Noah story. This is yet another warning for mankind that it is never too late to start believing in God, and turning to Him for guidance and support.

Steve Carell is great, Morgan Freeman shines as God, and Lauren Graham is as beautiful as ever.

The animal scenes are cleverly done. Seeing some animals took me by surprise.

The scenes where Baxter's neighbors and the media simply point at him as some religious nut-job is not as powerful as seeing those same people run for their lives as the flood waters, as Baxter said would come, came.

Jon Stewart's cameo was not needed. How the man still has a career is beyond me. He isn't funny, and the only 'jackass' in this movie is Jon himself.

Anyways, I hope people who check Evan ALmighty out actually think deeper than what they see on the screen. There is a message here, and it is not too hard to find.

Oh yeah, it seems Heather Langenkamp (Anderson) now works behind the scenes. I'm happy to see her working at all.

This movie is really funny, like really FUNNY! This movie gets an instant 10/10 from me. I loved it when Evan Baxter started to grow a beard and when he tries to shave it, the hair keeps on growing back. I cracked up when he had to wear a ponytail and braid his beard in order to go to work and make it unnoticeable to his co-workers. I was like "Is that Moses or God?" when I saw Evan with white hair and a disheveled robe. When Congressman Long (Who people were referring to as "That Fat Guy") was about to curse out at Evan, I laughed when all the birds decided to take a crap on him. That was the most funniest scene ever.

review_title: It's funny, hilarious and yet deep and moving. Not another silly comedy.
review_detailed_main: It's not just funny, its makes you laugh really hard. And it is touching and moving at the same time. Half time I was crying with laughter, half time I was crying with emotion. Altogether, I just still can't believe I liked it that much! Give it a try, you won't regret. Steve Carrel is better than ever, Molly Shannon has a small but traditionally goofy role. A short appearance of Jon Steward just completes it, and Morgan Freeman, that guy rocks the most. The plot is unconventional yet made with such an ease that makes the whole things very powerful and impressive. Not being a fan of comedies myself, I do recommend Evan Almighty.
